21.26.text: So, on that basis, I feel like I've really arrived.

67.26.text: in British politics or American politics,

71.26.text: and that is: We have run out of money.

88.26.text: that there's one question in politics at the moment above all other,

100.26.text: or to improve government, or to improve so many of the things

136.26.text: And the really simple argument I want to make tonight,

138.26.text: the really straightforward argument is this:

140.26.text: That if we combine the right political philosophy, the right political thinking,

146.26.text: with the incredible information revolution that has taken place,

150.26.text: and that all of you know so much more about than I do,

154.26.text: I think there's an incredible opportunity to actually remake politics,

161.26.text: and achieve what's up on that slide, which is a big increase in our well-being.

166.26.text: That's the argument I want to make tonight.

169.26.text: So, starting with the political philosophy.

172.26.text: Now I'm not saying for a minute that British Conservatives have all the answers.

177.26.text: But there are two things at heart that I think drive a conservative philosophy

182.26.text: that are really relevant to this whole debate.

184.26.text: The first is this: We believe that if you give people

186.26.text: more power and control over their lives,

189.26.text: if you give people more choice,

191.26.text: if you put them in the driving seat,

193.26.text: then actually, you can create a stronger and better society.

196.26.text: And if you marry this fact with the incredible abundance

200.26.text: of information that we have in our world today,

202.26.text: I think you can completely, as I've said,

204.26.text: remake politics, remake government, remake your public services.

209.26.text: The second thing we believe is we believe in going with the grain of human nature.

213.26.text: Politics and politicians will only succeed

216.26.text: if they actually try and treat with people as they are,

221.26.text: rather than as they would like them to be.

224.26.text: Now, if you combine this very simple, very conservative thought --

227.26.text: go with the grain of human nature --

229.26.text: with all the advances in behavioral economics,

232.26.text: some of which we were just hearing about,

234.26.text: again, I think we can achieve a real increase in well-being,

237.26.text: in happiness, in a stronger society

240.26.text: without necessarily having to spend a whole lot more money.

244.26.text: Now, why do I think now is the moment to make this argument?

248.26.text: Well, I'm afraid you're going to suffer a short, condensed history lesson

255.26.text: the pre-bureaucratic age, the bureaucratic age

259.26.text: and what we now live in, which I think is a post-bureaucratic age.

264.26.text: is that we have gone from a world of local control,

268.26.text: then we went to a world of central control,

271.26.text: and now we're in a world of people control.

273.26.text: Local power, central power, now, people power.

388.26.text: Now, what does this mean for our politics,

391.26.text: for our public services, for our government?

394.26.text: Well I can't, in the time I've got, give huge numbers of examples,

398.26.text: but let me just give a few of the ways that life can change.

403.26.text: And this is so obvious, in a way, because

405.26.text: you think about how all of you have changed

407.26.text: the way we shop, the way we travel, the way that business is done.

414.26.text: has actually gone all the way through our societies in so many different ways,

418.26.text: but it hasn't, in every way, yet touched our government.

423.26.text: Well, I think there are three chief ways that it should make an enormous difference:

427.26.text: in transparency, in greater choice and in accountability,

597.26.text: Now I also said the other principle

599.26.text: that I think we should work on is understanding of people,

605.26.text: you can achieve so much more.

696.26.text: Here are my two favorite U.S. speeches of the last 50 years.

704.26.text: Obviously, here we have JFK with that incredibly simple

710.26.text: "Ask not what your country can do for you; ask what you can do for your country,"

717.26.text: But when he made that speech, what could you do

720.26.text: to build the stronger, better society?

722.26.text: You could fight for your country, you could die for your country,

725.26.text: you could serve in your country's civil service,

727.26.text: but you didn't really have the information and the knowledge

731.26.text: and the ability to help build the stronger society in the way that you do now.

736.26.text: And I think an even more wonderful speech,

739.26.text: which I'm going to read a big chunk of,

743.26.text: which sums up what I said at the beginning

745.26.text: about believing there is more to life than money,

748.26.text: and more that we should try and measure than money.

751.26.text: And it is Robert Kennedy's beautiful description

753.26.text: of why gross national product captures so little:

756.26.text: It "does not allow for the health of our children,

759.26.text: the quality of their education, or the joy of their play.

762.26.text: It does not include the beauty of our poetry or the strength of our marriages,

766.26.text: the intelligence of our public debate.

768.26.text: It measures neither our wit nor our courage,

771.26.text: neither our wisdom nor our learning,

773.26.text: neither our compassion nor our devotion to our country.

778.26.text: except that which makes life worthwhile."

781.26.text: Again, a sentiment that was so noble and beautifully put 40 years ago,

786.26.text: and a beautiful dream 40 years ago,

789.26.text: but now with the huge advances in information technology,

793.26.text: with the massive changes in behavioral economics,

796.26.text: with all that we know about how you advance well-being,

800.26.text: that if we combine those insights

802.26.text: of giving power to people, and using information to make that possible,

806.26.text: and using the insight of going with the grain of human nature,

810.26.text: while at the same time, understanding why people behave in the way they do,

814.26.text: it is a dream more easy to realize today

818.26.text: than it was when it was made in that beautiful speech 40 years ago.
